justification: “The caregiving index was the primary outcome variable and consisted of seven questions, each accompanied by a 5-point Likert scale… Cronbach's αs of >.89 indicated good internal consistency across the seven items.”

topic_or_construct: principle of care (moral obligation to help)
justification: “Scores on the caregiving index correlate (r = .36) with principle of care, an index of the position that one is morally obliged to help those in need.”

measured_by: Empathic Concern sub-scale of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index
justification: “It is also associated with high scores on the empathic concern sub-scale of the interpersonal reactivity index…”

measured_by: Distrust of Others sub-scale of the Machiavellianism Scale
justification: “…and lower scores on the distrust of others sub-scale of the Machiavellianism scale.”

measured_by: Chronic Pain Grade Scale (original or revised)
justification: “To assess chronic pain levels we used the Chronic Pain Grade Scale, in its original (studies 3a or 3b) or newly revised form (study 3c).”
“…we included a measure of stigma, the eight-item Stigma Scale for Chronic Illnesses (SSCI-8) to assess people's sense that their value as a social partner has declined due to their illness.”

measured_by: 6-item Illness Legitimacy Measure (derived from caregiving index)
justification: “To more directly measure the perception that other people think one's illness is legitimate, the correlational study (3a) used a 6-item measure, derived from the caregiving index used in studies 1 and 2.”

measured_by: 8-item Treatment Acceptance Scale (benign vs aversive treatments)
justification: “In all three studies, treatment acceptance was assessed by asking participants if they would accept a series of treatments… Four items assessed preferences for benign treatments… and the other four items assess preferences for more aversive treatments.”
